author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
I have many thoughts but I would probably lead with this. You are likely learning what’s “correct” on the internet, having been in the game for a minute I can tell you that 90% of what you are reading is wrong, or incomplete or misses the point

Your clients however will be your greatest teachers. I learn more every year than the last, and I’m 31 years into record life and 23’in mastering

Clients understand music intuitively, they are reaching for something bigger than LUFS, and tonal balance curves. Keep an open ear, write short emails and you’ll keep learning

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
In this house we believe

- that +0.5 dB at 16k is what matters 
- Linear phase EQ is a war crime
- Noise shaped dither is for suckers

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Just for reference, the convo was to restrict my approach to one band of EQ, Q of no sharper than .7 and maybe a low shelf. That's it. And a limiter.

Since then I've done at least over 100 songs, many of which are out in the world and/or on their way to release. So a decent time to circle back with some insight. However, compared to more experienced ears on here I am still a baby.

Extremely powerful challenge from Ruairi, and it really made me think in broad terms about what EQ is doing, what my goals are when using it, and how each part relates to another. And what you gain or lose when making a move. I would highly recommend it, and found it very very hard. It's non-trivial to make things sound better when you actually hear what's happening.

 I've also been pretty lucky to work on quite a bit of music that I would have considered outside of my experience range, and I think this gentler approach worked well there because the mixes were already pretty damn good. So there's that too!

Of course for work where I'm being paid I'm not only restricting to one band, I do whatever is needed but even so many times I would prefer that. It felt like "learning scales" but for mastering in a way. And loudness really is down mostly to EQ, as far as I can tell!

author: Nick Stetina
content:
Right. That ended up being my approach, not taking it as a prescriptive EQ order but just sussing out from that what they were trying to achieve.

A .1db tilt shelf and a few EQ moves no more than +/- .5db later and they “love it”. It was honestly a coin toss to me if they were going to reply that they couldn’t hear a difference, ha. Maybe that scratched their itch to have *some* input? 

In any case, they’re happy and I think not jumping into an even tactful version of “alright what’s really going on here” helped preserved the ‘experience’ a bit. When the customer sends their steak back the first time, serve up a new one to their liking right away. If they send it back again…maybe it’s okay for the chef to walk out and (politely) see wtf is going on 👨🏻‍🍳

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: ALXCPH
content: Funny timing! 10 minutes ago i was dynamically eq’ing some anoying ringing frequencies out of an acoustic guitar. Using Pro Q 3. I tried ZL, NP and LP. After A/Bing, I went with the Linear Phase option on high. To my surprise it just sounded better then the other two. So I stuck with it. Goes to show, no rules in audio are absolute. 99.9% I never go with linear phase eq’s l, but today I did.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Then I have to be on the lookout for all the stuff I don't want to be, because now anything's possible: True Peak limiting even when it sounds worse. Linear Phase EQ because it's "better." The default HPF at 30 and LPF at 18kHz. etc etc. I end up QCing someone else's work when that's not really my job. And if the song had just gone to one of my usual MEs I would have listened through once and been fine with it.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
On that note, can't remember where I found this but a related piano recipe from Michael Brauer. Hoping he hasn't trademarked this one so the Discord doesn't get shut down.



"Remember the early Elton John records? Remember how his piano shimmered? At mediasound we loved that sound so a lot of us were always playing around with getting different versions of it. No lacquered hammers, no Dolby A off, just a combination of compression and EQ.


I only recorded Luther's voice, may he rest in peace, on that song along with "searching" and then mixed both. Luther was on a whole other level of singers. He walked into that session and listened to the song in the control room once, then he walked out into the studio with the lyric sheet in his hand. What you hear on"Glow of Love" and "searching" is his first fun down reading the lyrics from a yellow pad. No punches.


The piano sound you’re referring to is probably the same one that I did for Vandross on the “Never too much” song.


Ok, this is how you do it.

1. First insert an LA3A or LA2A (depending on the version of sound you’re going after) across the stereo piano tracks. The LA2A is good if the song is slow and the chords are quarter notes. The LA3A is good if the chords are faster with a harder attack like in “never too much”. Bang those meters and 
2. out of the compressor go into a couple of pultecs and push up..way up the 3 or 5 k on the low end and the 8 or 10 k on the high end. Don’t be safe. 
3. Now go to the desk EQ and start clearing out some of the muddiness and EQ up the remaining mids so that it just shimmers like a baby. 
4. When it’s done right, you can hear the harmonics riding up during each sustain.  
5. I remember hearing that song on the radio and man that piano was making me feel good all over. Sounds pretty simple when you know how to do it right?”

author: Øra Mastering
content:
I always end up chasing my tail when separating tonal and loudness. If I get the right tonal balance first, then everything shifts around when adding loudness/limiting. To me all limiters and limiter styles within have different tones, at least if I’m limiting more then a couple of dB. For that reason I always start with finding the right limiter/style that keeps or changes the tonal balance the way I want (too bright mix = dark limiter, dull mix = bright limiter, great mix = limiter that keeps the balance when pushed ect.). Once I have the loudness and given the tonal balance a gentle push in the right direction with the limiter, I get the track over the finish line with eq or other tools in front of the limiter. 

This is not meant as criticism of your approach, I just haven’t cracked that code.
Hats of to you for making that work!

author: Bonati12461
content: Love a tilt EQ. I use the Gyraf tilt one (older one that's tube only, no solid state option) and I have a preset I set up for myself in Fabfilter Q2 when I want to tweak. It would be very weird to use a LOT of tilt EQ on something (have done it though) because a little goes such a long way. Maybe I just work on weirder shit than the rest of you. I throw a bunch of processing at certain things, no shame at all.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
In my experience (again, caveated by it being rather limited compared to some on here), a gentle shelf wins most of the time.

This isn’t quite like soothe, but I’ve found success in certain situations using the weiss ds1-mk3 in the low pass mode, so it is only working on the area below the filter (as I understand it, and it appears to me). This seems to my ears to not have the bad multiband smearing problems of say fabfilter mb, etc

In situations where the dynamics down there are out of whack and you need to control the groove better it can really work great, but that specific plugin has odd release characteristics that take time to understand. That same flexibility can allow some subtle control down there that can actually accentuate the groove and fix your problems at the same time.

As with everything, there are trade offs, it can make the low end sound odd if not careful, and you really need a room that is accurate down there to judge it well I think (now that I’m in my current setup I can very clearly hear when it is helping or hurting)

author: Øra Mastering
content:
That makes sense, thanks for the explanation. Reading this, I don’t think we’re miles appart. I used to have one «default» limiter and focus all my moves in front of that, also adding limiter/loudness as the last step. When doing so, I always found myself having to tweak the moves (that I already had «perfectly» dialed in) because everything would change when adding the final limiter. That’s when I would be chasing my tail 😅
Now I start with getting the limiter right for the song and then doing eq moves as the second step. This way it it a lot less back and forth for me. I should say I only use one limiter at the time and the limiters I audition with are dmg limitless, fabfilter pro-l2 and Ozone maximizer, with styles I know well. Dmg usually gets used on acoustic and jazz, pro-l2 & ozone for pop/rock. If it is music with vocals I find different styles can really change the way the vocals are percieved, so it’s mostly chosing the style that support the vocals best that is the goal. Using two minuttes to get the right limiter from the start saves me time and uncertainty down the road, and in some cases let’s me use less eq to get the desired result.
There are many roads to Rome as they say, I was just interested in yours bc whenever I tried that it ended in a lot of second guessing (for me!). 

Do you find yourself having to add more eq when adding limiter at the end to keep the tonal balance you have acheived?

author: spectrummasters
content:
...so, the short answer jack is yes , the wide q eq moves are definitely advantageous and applicable outside of the mastering stage (for my workflow)....very much so. I think in a way , the broad eq is sort of like a painter taking a few steps back from the canvas having been working up close on a detailed brushstroke (which I’d suggest for example is like a surgical eq move in a mix or saturating a sound at the production stage etc).....”stepping back” and listening not just to The minutiae but the overall tone i think is a discipline that is potentially easy to forget in mix mode ......and in a sense this is how the broad EQ is serving me . I find the eq points ruairi shared work v well at the group bus stage also......for light touches

With regards to whether I’m only mastering . No, currently my most common paid work comes from local / independent artists in my network I’ve built mostly from my local community outwards through word of mouth. This is primarily in the rnb/trap/hip-hop genres and for better or worse it appears to have been normalised that when someone wants a mix....what they want is a mixter. I’m with Derek Ali’s Enginears platform and even there they are promoting a free master from us as mixers on the platform.
Personally, I’m not against certain mixers mastering as well....but i think this is more genre specific.....and also v much down to the individual. I think you spoke about your arc on here into mastering and others have too. ....i believe there is much to benefit from having professional mastering engineers, with thousands of hours under their belt listening to thousands of tracks in excellent environments......take the final listen and make the final adjustments on a mix..and for me, i consider myself on a career arc towards becoming that .

author: Jeremy Klein

author: Iwan Morgan
content:
Interesting response by Chris Gehringer in the new MWTM Q+A section: 

*"Dereck, You really hit home with this one.
I’m 99% ITB for over 10 years was well. I was more hybrid earlier on during my conversion period and now mostly all in due to my workflow and client time demands.

I definitely feel like i’m chasing Refs with the same plugins used by mixers and producers sometimes and don’t feel creative but that’s the game lately. I really feel this is the main problem. I’m not really happy when i’m pushed in that direction.
With almost everyone having the same plugins it’s very apparent that most masters in a shootout sound the same now. No surprises there.

Is Analog Better?

I recently bought a Terry Audio CEQ to try and change my sound and it definitely works. It has an amazing sound and color that cannot be found in most plugins. That being said it doesn’t work for me all the time.
Many of the projects i work on are so loud and pushed anything run through analog gear loses the “glue” that is in the digital mix.
I also just got a Sontec MES-432D9D from Make Believe Studios.
It actually sounds like the real thing to me. It has a much different vibe when using it. I find myself using different frequencies from other EQs.
Is That Better? I’m not sure yet but getting good results when i use both of these tools.

I think the most important part of my setup is that I’m very familiar with my plugins and know when to use different ones when necessary (its also so easier to try another one if you’re not sure obviously)
I’m constantly trying to stay fresh and not mail it in.

Not sure if there’s an actual answer for this but i hope i answered some of your question or at least validated our situation.

Chris"*

author: Paris Lee
content:
The EQ section on the MLA 4 is fucking excellent and different than conventional eq sound. Bump the mid band half a db (top of low range to a mid range 3k-8k. Killer

It has a great hi shelf de-esser 

Turning down 100-200hz half a db can really relax the low end that a shelf on other eq’s does not do.

The eq is where it’s at. The compression is just a slight slight squeezer. 

Low band on dance tracks *GENTLY* no visible GR or rare GR lights 
Hi band de ess - starting point 3m attack 50m release)

author: hebakadry
content: I think time spent de-essing vocals and treating HF content in vinyl prepped masters overrides worrying about how much limiting there is in my opinion. The amount of limiting and how good/bad the cut is really pertinent on the program material itself.  Not the actual amount of gain reduction you are doing because the cutter will literally just turn everything down anywhere between 8-10dB before the signal hits the amps. Excessive sibilance, on a hyper compressed rock record with insane splashy over compressed cymbals and out of control HF information will result in the dull cuts you get back from most plants where you don’t have access to the cutting engineer.  They do this because they want to create a playback safe record and avoid a very expensive $10k mistake like blowing a cutterhead if their amp breakers aren’t calibrated right.  Instead of spot de-essing problem on one song or spot treating problem songs on a side, they will opt for broad stroke moves (HF limiting, EQ, global de-essing) and that can be a bit of death sentence to the quality of the cut and put everyone off vinyl as a format.  Which I think is an incredible format with well crafted engineering.  Also I strongly believe that every record doesn’t belong on vinyl…but that’s another convo.

author: Nick Stetina
content: Feeling close to moving this convo over to #👩🍳mixing-talk , but you might want to try out GainAim. I found it useful to ‘groom’ dialogue ahead of other processing on a documentary project recently. It was helpful to think of it as just part of the equation instead of finding *the* setting that will park your dialogue where it needs to be. I.e. - GainAim pass followed by a compressor, or a GainAim pass focusing on broad stroke leveling > another GainAim pass with a faster speed setting acting more like word by word clip gain.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Linear phase is a made-up necessity by big plugin conglomerates. 

It’s potentially mathematically helpful for multi-mic sources, but in mastering, I don’t see a benefit. Even with multi-mic sources, I’m more apt to avoid HPF/LPF and opt for shelving/bells on a non-linear phase eq than reach for the linear phase tool. 

Also, nearly every bit of processing will affect the phase somehow. There’s no sense in being so precious with phase that we stop listening to tone.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
That's fantastic, @ALXCPH. My all-or-nothing hot take on linear phase was more in the spirit of “making assertions” (in Seth Godin’s terminology). 

Honestly, my caveat to my previous statement is that linear phase processing is likely operating in a lot of plugins behind the scenes. Many times when I'm using RX, I notice processes adding the pre or post ring of linear phase even if that's not an option I'm selecting.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’m potentially missing the point here (there are probably reasons you mastering lot stay in RX rather than Tools), but… could you apply the workflow I use for declicking audio in PT to what you’re looking for above?

Eg - lead vocal will almost certainly have some clicks. I duplicate playlist (with suffix _Dclk), open up RX DeClick in Audiosuite and set to stun. Render it on the whole playlist indiscriminately while reading LWMR discord.

Flip back to the main playlist. Listen through with an egregious high shelf and a boatload of compression - comp up from the _Dclk playlist whenever you hit a click. 

Maybe some combo of this idea with Batch processing in RX could speed things up?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But like any filter it’s a trade off best judged by ear. Steeper slopes and lower cutoffs will clean up aliasing, but at a cost to transients. Not all aliasing is bad, and not all transients are good or worth preserving! But linear phase for sure

author: spectrummasters
content:
@Nomograph Mastering  right, ruari class finished ! .....ok so, ive a lot of thoughts ...this exercise has made a v big impression on me .
Off top, 

According to RX The mix is at -7.2 LUFS integrated , -6.3 short term, TP -0.1

The artist wants a "bit more low-end " on a fast paced, alt/pop/rock track.
And Imo a little air on top would compliment the mix.
(starting at -7.2 is loud for my experience so its a good challenge and these sort of Lufs are what i want to become v comfortable working at where currently im more comfortable around -9.)

SO i start with your 10 eq points in place , with your q settings and .5 db limits in fabfilter pro q 3  .

Thoughts:

It became clear immediately how powerful to me these q settings and eq points are, with regards to re-shaping the tonal balance.
I cannot recall ever having only used these curves , nor in the absence of any other processing. 
Listening to the impact of 0.1 db up or down in the different areas was remarkable. 

After half an hour id got to something i was v happy with, that appeared "Louder " to me and also.....a bit more lows and a little more open on top. Which id call a success.

Id brought the Pro q output down 0.4db to compensate the gain increase and printed with no limiter.

In RX this printed version showed as -7.2 LUFS integrated , -6.3 short term, TP 0.0 .

Ideally id have not touched this again.....i really liked it. 

Following instructions i then put the L2 Limiter on (modern mode , +0.1 db, TP on and output -0.1) .

Truth be told, once id put the limiter on i wanted to go back into the EQ because i didnt like the sound anymore, i felt the L2 spoilt it.

author: spectrummasters
content: I considered your points where you’ve discussed how broad stroke analogue gear can be at times tho and  in my limited experience with some Ssl and neve bits I have I have to agree

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I have a single low shelf on it

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I have nowhere near the experience Ruairi does, but I have never done it either; or wanted to. It feels so much like a “rule” that has for some reason become accepted, I’ve never heard it feel any better, it always feels worse to me, even when “technically” better

The closest I have come is maybe a very gentle low shelf cutting some sides; this is like once or twice to clear up the groove down there

author: Maxim
content: Any of you ever reach for a tilt eq? And if not, why?

author: Edward Rivera
content: Brighter ? Darker ? Tilt eq...but more often than not, just for brighter

author: Edward Rivera
content: And since its such a broad stroke, it will most likely be early int he chain

author: Maxim
content: Yeah tilt eq in mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Man, I'm doing some writing atm and Tilt EQs are such a perfect example of what I am trying to understand and describe

author: Will Melones
content: Has anyone (in the history of music) used the Pro-Q tilt *shelf*? I just can’t wrap my head around the why of that option.

author: Will Melones
content: I suppose it has the same application as a tilt band, but without getting more extreme at the lower and upper frequency limits. It just feels chaotic to me, like a single shelf would do the job more precisely.

author: Deleted User
content: I just started using the mixland one. I like it on individual sources, I love that you can really find a sweet spot for the presence of a sound and it allows you to move quickly. But for Mastering I think it might be too broad stroke in most cases

author: Rollmottle
content: Shelf city. The First Order shelf Ruairi baked into in his Equilibrium default is nice and gentle. You can set it out of audible band and it's still doing work up in the audible band.

author: omarakrouche
content: Feel like this is a pultec cut moment

author: Rollmottle
content: big question...i broadly think about the digital EQ as "corrective," as in framing the song to where i think it needs to sit, not necessarily technical correction. (the RX stage is where that happens). sometimes that's the end of it if the mix is good enough. but sometimes there's more to be had and that's typically when i go analog. not that i don't think digital couldn't also get me there, but that the analog does it in a way i find more pleasing and faster. i probably have the luxury of more time than Ruairi does per project and if my circumstances changed, my approach might change. in broad strokes, that's how my brain thinks about it.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
😂😂😂

I suppose I meant an actually reliable AI.

It seems feasible an AI could QC a downsample or alt version given a high res render with confidence no? Just check that everything went as it should by comparing the files, which is what we do

Not so simple I know, just broad stroke possibilities

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Question for those of you using a G14 or other Gyraf gear - what level are you running at? I'm testing the buffer from this Pultec circuit (same as G14 as far as I can tell) but it's completely crunching at any reasonable level. Even when I turn my converters down to +13dBu I can't play anything at full scale without it crunching. If I back it down 3dB from there it's OK but that's super low compared to +19dBu levels and the noise floor of it is pretty high

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Pultec circuit needs 26dB gain IIRC so if you are only getting 12 something is off

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Also there are ways of listening that once you click you can’t unhear. Like once you understand what linear phase is doing you can spot it a mile away

author: David Fuller
content: It would be nice if I could have a controller dedicated to that Metric Halo Sontec plug

content:
@hyanrarvey fascinated to know…but totally understand if you don’t want to share…how many units does a plug like the sontec sell? 

Broad strokes…thousands? Tens of thousands?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Should be very clean in RX, do the steepest filter you can, right under 48k, linear phase

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Preringing is 1 I think, whatever is fully linear phase

author: Rob Domos
content: Also as an aside, I’m surprised to see Randy Merrill using narrow Q m/s eq

author: Rollmottle
content: shelfing down from there to turn down the shit i can hear

author: cian riordan
content: Linear Phase tangent here... you have two identical tracks (let's say a mult of a drum stem)... and you want to process one heavy handedly and leave the other natural... but you need to EQ the processed one. I'm still in the belief that linear phase EQ is the best solution for this problem... AITAH?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I agitate against it in mastering because the accepted wisdom is that the heavy cpu linear phase EQ sounds better than regular, and it doesn’t for 99.9% of use cases

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I would say honestly, even in recording/mixing use cases that linear phase EQ is the better choice < 1% of the time

author: cian riordan
content: I found using linear phase LPF on the LFE channel in atmos when sending stuff in parallel was a must to keep the coherency.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s a pretty technical document but the key thing that pertains to the OP’s question is the filtering that happens before the loudness is calculated. The first stage of pre filtering is a very simple high shelf to account for the shape of the human head, the second is what matters here

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I’m 99% ITB. I occasionally run stuff through my Thermionic Culture gear but that is very rare and only when the client wants me to juice the signal. I usually use Izotope/DMG and Ryan’s Sontec

author: BoozleBAM
content: Sorry to dig this up, but I basically do this exact thing with my kick drum, and I look forward to experimenting with linear phase this afternoon, which is something I basically wrote off after finding it to be quite "stiff" feeling when I did the "duplicate a bass track and then put a chorus on it and highpass it with a linear phase" thing... My kick drum does feel a bit "smeary" at times with all the heavy eqing/ processing, though. So yeah... excited to give this a go. Thank you.

author: BoozleBAM
content: Does linear phase mostly find its relevance in the lower frequencies for some reason?? That is mostly when I hear of people using it - when the lower freqs are in play...

author: miguel @ knurlmastering
content: I still think that linear phase EQing is very program-dependent, more than anything else. On the Weiss EQ1, I use both standard and linear phase modes; most of the time, one just works better than the other and is usually noticeable. It’s one of those things that I’ve stopped trying to intellectualize and just go with what sounds best on a per-case basis. It’s very hard to specify exact scenarios where one will always be better than the other, at least for music production! So while in theory one might be better than the other for a specific task, not all music handles EQing the same way.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For the kinds of small corrections we do in RX the smearing is mostly a non issue. I’m allergic to the sound of linear phase anything but I have no issue with how RX sounds on brief spectral edits

author: masteredbyjack
content: Probably depends on the gear though, Fearn is very broad stroke

author: Will Pragnell
content: I have a track here with a kick that is almost all sub, very few harmonics, and is also way too loud. As it happens, this is a mix that someone wanted feedback on before sending for mastering, so I can help them fix it, but I also took it as an opportunity to do a practice master on the current version. Best results so far have come from setting up a dynamic low shelf in Nova, which helps to take the excessive low end boom out of play, but obviously doesn't do anything to bring out the harmonics higher up and make the kick audible on smaller systems. Any suggestions for other things I could try (other than maybe getting crazy in RX)?

author: flyboystudio
content:
Hey all, first of all just want to say how stoked I am to have found this community! Discovered the LWMR podcasts a few months back and have truly loved listening and learning. 

I’ve had a note back from a ME that I’ve used a few times via an artist I work with, asking to send an unlimited version of the final mix. 
Final mix had the limiter off but I mixed into standard clip doing a couple db of soft clipping here and there, pretty minimal, so left that on. 

Mix bus was: SSL G Comp - Maag EQ - Oxford Inflator - Standard Clip (Soft Clip Pro, 5% Saturation, 8 x oversampling). All very light touches along the way. 

Sent loud mix to A&R and artist (less than 2db reduction on limiter) but they also approved the pre master in this instance i.e with mix bus on but limiter off. 

Although the ME has the approved mix already, I’m thinking of sending a version without any clipping and asking to hear 2 versions…

Any thoughts welcomed!

author: agnusbeats
content:
Hey folks, first off just wanted to say I’m extremely grateful for stumbling across this group via LWMR - I’ve just been reading through the groups soaking up all the epic conversations, recommendations and knowledge that’s currently being shared!

I’ve recently been getting some feedback on mix + masters and recurrence has been that chorus’ and bigger sections of songs need more stereo width. There is major panning already happening within these tracks… so I’ve been trialing out imaging tools such as S1 imager, Ozone Imager, T-racks imager, Microshift & Doubler. I’m aware it’s important to be cautious with these plug-ins as they can introduce phasing issues. I’m also finding the stereo sound these plug ins are producing sounds - fake, thin, untasteful and feels as thought is alters the song in negative way. 

At times I thought maybe I’m need more instrumentation within these arrangement to play with panning - but I hear absolutely gorgeous tracks that are simply a vocal and an acoustic guitar that have such a rich deep stereo field (almost as if there were 2 acoustic gtr’s) 

I’ve been starting to play with M/S eq and have been having some small wins - but would appreciate and thoughts, views, opinions or direction!

Thanks team 🙏🏼

author: tinkerjef
content: Hmm the linear phase would make sense on a track level EQ move, but I don’t see the difference on the master?

author: onanisland
content: Linear Phase shouldn't shift phase

author: onanisland
content: But I will def check the Linear Phase

author: Halliemmelton
content:
But I’ve definitely heard it when switching between modes in pro-q even with no actual eq’ing inserted. Not on every song, but it wasn’t an isolated incident!

I also almost never use linear phase mode in general

author: onanisland
content: I've used weiss, maat, and others (which are all linear phase equalizers) on many occeasions on orchestral, ballads, etc where I needed the stereo image to stay as it is

author: Halliemmelton
content: Yeah I’d just normally use Weiss for that purpose rather than use pro-q in linear phase, namedly because of the issues I’ve seen before with that mode on pro-q

author: David Fuller
content: EQ feels a bit too broad stroke for this

author: Ted Whitten Media
content:
When doing revisions, does anyone save a whole new project file with a version number appended to the end? Wondering if that might help me stay more organized. Currently working on an album where the client wanted to go back to V1 for release, and I swear I kept track of every move I'd made to get to v2, but for some reason I just couldn't get it to sound exactly like V1 again. It's no problem on their end because they just used the file I'd rendered and uploaded to Samply. But now I have a clip in my montage that doesn't match the released version, which I don't like. I ended up dropping the master on a reference track instead.

I think this issue was partially caused because I tend to send an initial rough master too early in the process and they get demo-itis. For some reason I've always wanted to send clients an initial rough master after I've done the quick "from the gut" broad strokes, but before I've totally nailed down the nitty gritty stuff, to see if they like the direction I'm headed. And all too often they end up liking the first version.

Or maybe I'm just overthinking v2 and making it worse on a regular basis? I dunno... 😂

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content: To see how much I could get from mastering alone - I will say I try and touch each of these very gently for several broad strokes, but the sentiment I’m hearing is them be too many strokes

author: James Cronier
content:
There’s a lot of tweak-ability with Standard Clip’s oversampling and filter. Personally, I’d get my ears familiar with the oversampling amounts and the non-over sampled setting in the plugin. Some of those settings are pretty hard to differentiate, but some have clear differences. The clipping will sound different.

Then I’d play with default linear phase vs minimum phase oversampling filter. That difference is readily apparent to my ears. 

The slope and frequency of the filters have an incredible amount of variability. There are a staggering amount of possible settings. I can’t offer much on the sound of those changes. Maybe others can offer more insight.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Anyone else finding that when you copy a plugin chain across to other clips in the wavelab montage that the settings aren't always copying?  I noticed it today.  Standard clip changed from the prest Hard Clip to Soft Clip and Pro L2 's output was back up to 0.00 rather than -0.30 which I wanted it to be.  Equilibrium and Sontec seemed to be fine.
